dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 5215 IH: Beef Origin Labeling Accountability Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Johnson of South Dakota introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means

form.official-title: To require the United States Trade Representative, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, to determine a means of reinstating mandatory country of origin labeling for beef that is in compliance with all applicable rules of the World Trade Organization, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Beef Origin Labeling Accountability Act.

section.header: Reinstatement of mandatory country of origin labeling for beef

subsection.text: The United States Trade Representative, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, shall determine a means of reinstating mandatory country of origin labeling for beef that is in compliance with all applicable rules of the World Trade Organization.

Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, and every 180 days thereafter as appropriate, the United States Trade Representative shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report that includes—

paragraph.text: a description of progress in meeting the requirements of subsection (a); and

recommendations for legislation to implement the requirements of subsection (a), including the means of reinstating mandatory country of origin labeling for beef, if necessary, as well as engagements with the Trade Representative’s counterparts in other governments on this matter.

subsection.header: Consultations To resolve WTO dispute settlements
subsection.text: The United States Trade Representative shall seek to enter into consultations with—

paragraph.text: the Trade Representative’s counterpart in the Government of Canada to resolve the matters involved in the World Trade Organization’s dispute settlement identified as DS384 and titled United States–Certain Country of Origin Labeling Requirements; and

the Trade Representative’s counterpart in the Government of Mexico to resolve the matters involved in the World Trade Organization’s dispute settlement identified as DS386 and titled United States–Certain Country of Origin Labeling Requirements.

subsection.text: In this section, the term appropriate congressional committees means—

paragraph.text: the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives; and
the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry and the Committee on Finance of the Senate.
